description.narrative:
Oxfam Mekong Regional Water Governance Program (MRWGP) seeks to promote the inclusion of civil society and local communities in water resource governance and decision-making. Over the strategic period of the Mekong Water Governance Program (2020-2024), the goal is to contribute to more women and men in the riparian community along the Greater Mekong region realizing their rights to secure andsustainable livelihoods.
Over the next four years, the Mekong Water Governance Project will address all the five strategic priority of the Mekong Program: 1. Inclusion of civil society in water governance 2. Gender equality and women’s leadership in water resource management: Ensure more women are effectively participating in and influencing decision-making andgender equality becomes a central consideration in water governance. 3. Civil Society capacity building and networking: Ensure civil society are effectively participating in and influencing policies and practices related to water governance 4. Communityand Community Based Natural Resources Management (CBNRM) 5. Government and Private Sector (in the thematic area of Hydropower and Sustainable Energy): Promote constructive and basin-wide dialogues on more sustainable and equitable energy options and pathways.
Oxfam in Vietnam will provide support and manage partners in Vietnam with proposed activities for the Y2 (April 2021-March 2022) will be a ‘light touch’ focusing on:
1. Work with MDY to support Local women empowerment project in water resources conservation in Kien Giang province.” - To raise awareness of local women about importance of water source protection, water quality monitoring, conservation of wetland resources for their sustainable livelihood benefits; - To identify local women champions to debate and challenge local decision-making processes on water resources management.
2. To support youths to complete their final dissertation research thesis with selected research areas around: climate adaptive, community-led water smartagriculture (adaptive to new context of extreme weather events such as more severe drought and saline water during dry months, less/lower flood water during wet season; small-scale solar energized irrigation schemes; dualuse of solar PV within farming areas, (i.e. for energy such as lighting, combining with operating shrimp farm/ drying agricultural products, irrigation, etc.); smart waste collection and processing initiatives; low-cost household-based water desalination models; smart rainwater harvesting and safe storage.
